title: Bilateral Asymmetric Sensorineural Hearing Loss (Ménière’s Disease & Presbycusis)
chief_complaint: My hearing is much worse in my right ear compared to my left. I've been told I have Ménière’s disease on that side. I'm here to see if I'm a candidate for a cochlear implant or if new hearing aid technology, like a BiCROS, would help me.

problem_summary.course: Right ear hearing loss progressed due to Ménière’s disease; Left ear decreased gradually over time.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: History of noise exposure. No current active otologic symptoms reported.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Significant difficulty due to asymmetry and severity of loss in the right ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Interested in Cochlear Implant or BiCROS technology.

history.present_illness: Patient reports bilateral hearing loss, worse in the right. Right ear loss is attributed to Ménière’s disease; Left ear to presbycusis and noise exposure.
history.otologic_history: Previous MRI was normal. Previous audiogram approx 1 year ago.
history.noise_exposure_history: Positive history of noise exposure reported.
history.prior_management: Considering new technology (BiCROS) or surgical intervention (CI).

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Severe to profound SNHL (250-1000 Hz) rising to severe (2000-8000 Hz). Left ear: Moderate sloping to severe SNHL (250-6000 Hz), rising to moderately severe at 8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: SAT obtained due to severity; poor agreement with PTA likely due to rising configuration. WRS could not be measured (CNT). Left ear: SRT in agreement with PTA; WRS shows slight difficulty.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Not performed at this visit as there were no significant changes from previous assessments.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral, asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss. The right ear exhibits a 'reverse slope' severe-to-profound loss consistent with Ménière’s disease, with no usable word recognition ability. The left ear shows a moderate sloping to severe loss with preserved speech discrimination (80%).
counseling_points: Your right ear has very limited ability to understand speech, even if we make sounds louder, which is why standard hearing aids might not help on that side.
We have two main options to discuss: A BiCROS hearing aid system or a Cochlear Implant evaluation.
A BiCROS system would place a microphone on your right ear to send sound wirelessly to a hearing aid in your left ear. This helps you hear sounds from your 'bad' side.
A Cochlear Implant is a surgical option that could potentially restore some hearing to the right ear directly, rather than just routing sound to the left.
notes_for_actor: You are knowledgeable about your diagnosis (Ménière’s disease).
You are proactive and specifically asking about 'BiCROS' or 'Cochlear Implants'.
You do not have active vertigo or fullness today, just the hearing loss.
